meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Islamists Out, Somalia Tries to Rise From Chaos

In just two weeks, Somalia's political world has been turned upside down, with the militant Islamist forces that ruled much of the nation for the past six months driven out by Ethiopian troops. But dire needs remain in the dusty, chaotic, forlorn wrecks of its cities: food, water, shelter, fire protection, law, order -- and hope.
PAGE A5
Harvard May Choose A Woman as President

The search to replace Lawrence H. Summers, who resigned as president of Harvard last February amid fierce faculty discontent, is secretive, but the list of candidates includes three women who are Ivy League presidents.
PAGE A12
Toyota Learns to Swagger
Toyota, traditionally a careful company, is making surprisingly aggressive moves at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
2 Dead in Newark Shooting
Two men were fatally shot in Newark yesterday, less than 24 hours before Mayor Cory A. Booker was to reveal a new initiative against drugs and violent crime.
PAGE B1
Changing Ballet's Landscape
The young British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon is forming a new classical dance company in New York, a city accustomed to two established giants.
THE ARTS, PAGE E1
Eagles and Patriots Make It A Bad Day for New York
The Philadelphia Eagles and the New England Patriots made sure the Giants and the Jets had short stays in the N.F.L. playoffs.

The Eagles beat the visiting Giants, 23-20, on a 38-yard field goal as time expired in what was expected to be the final game for the Giants star Tiki Barber, above. Philadelphia will play at New Orleans on Saturday.
The Patriots took advantage of a Jets fumble and an interception to win, 37-16, as Tom Brady threw for two touchdowns. Sunday, in the second round, New England will face San Diego.
SPORTSMONDAY, PAGE D1
